original_text:
You should join the Seagoing Cowgirls program. The cattle-boat trips are an unbeliveable opportunity for a small-town girl. Besides helping people, Luke had the side benefit of seeing Europe and China. But when Luke went to see the Acropoils in Greece she said it was specail. She also said that gondola ride in Venice, Italy, a city with streets of water.

Luke also found fun time on board, especially on return trips after the animals had been unloaded. The cowgirls would have so much fun the would play baseball and volleyball in empty holds where animals had been housed. Table-tennis tournaments, fencing, boxing, reading, whittling, and games also helped pass time.

You should join the Seagoing Cowgirls program because you can have a lot of fun there its fun, helpful to people, entertainig you if you are bored and its cool and it has a lot of space. You can save people and animals. You can save the person if they are drowning by your boat or you can save an animals if they fall of your boat.

But being a Seagoing Cowgirl was much more than an adventure for Luke Bomberger. Luke said it opended up the world to her she said she is grateful for the opportunity. It made her more aware of people of other countries and there needs. That aware stayed with her, leading her family to hostess a number of international students and exchange visitors for many years.

Helping out her aunt Katie's farm as a girl had prepared Luke for hard work, but not for the dangers at sea. On her second trip, Luke served as night watchman. Her job was to check on all the animals every hour. One rainy night,after making her hourly report to the captain, she slide down a slippery ladder on her backside. Luke's heart racedas she shot feet first torwads the opening on the side of the ship. Thats when she figured out she had more room to play her games. I hoped that helped you and I hope you join the Seagoign Cowgirls program and thats why you should go you can experince different stuff that you never knew.

original_text:
Luck Bomberger was working two part-time jobs in a grocery store and a bank. Don Reist her friend invited her to go to Europe on a cattle boat.

She said yes right then she knew it was an opportunity of a lifetime.

UNRRA hired "Seagoing Cowgirls" to take care of the horses, young cows, and mules that were shipped overseas.

Luke signed up with her friend Don.

Before arriving in Greece, Luke turned 18 years old, which meant she could be drafted for military service.

When her draft board learned she was on a cattle-boat trip, they told her to keep doing that for her service.

By the time she was discharged in 1947, she had made 9 trips the most of any Seagoing Cowgirl.

The cattle boat trips were an unbelievable opportunity for Luke.

Besides helping people, she had the side benefit of seeing Europe and China.

But seeing the Acropolis in Greece was special.

Luke toured an excavated castle in Crete and marveled at the Panama Canal on her way to China.

It took about two weeks to cross the Atlantic Ocean from the eastern coast of the United States and a month to get to China.

Caring for the animals during the crossings kept her busy.

They had to be fed and watered two or three times a day.

Bales of hay and bags of oats had to be pulled up from the lower holds of the ship.

Stalls had to be cleaned.

Helping out on her aunt Katie's farm as a girl had prepared her for hard work, but not for dangers at sea.

She couldn't work for a couple of days because of cracked ribs.

Being a Seagoing Cowgirl was much more than an adventure for Luke.

It opened the world up to her.

She is grateful for the opportunity.

It made her more aware of people of other countries and their needs.

The awarness stayed with her, leading her family to hostess a number of international students and exchange visitors for many years.

original_text:
In the story "A Cowgirl Who Rides the Waves" a young adult named Luke signs up for a program that is called the "Seagoing Cowgirls" that take care of horses, young cows, and mules. The Seagoing Cowgirls do this because countries that were destroyed need them for travel and food. Now here are three reasons why Luke decided to join the Seagoing Cowgirls.

Luke signed up for the Seagoing Cowgirls because it was an opportunity of a life time. That means that she would not get anymore chances to travel on a boat around the world. This is also a big opportunity mostly because she is a farm girl from a small town. In paragraph 5 and 1 it states "... Luke couldn't say no. She knew it was an opportunity of a lifetime." "The cattle-boat trips were an unbeliveable opportunity for a small-town girl, but besides helping people, I had the side benefit of seeing Europe and China..." Also Luke wanted to join because she got to help countries that were damaged from the war. In the two sentences that were right before the first paragraph (the ones that help explain the story a little bit) it states " Luke Bomberger crossed the Atlantic Ocean 16 times and the Pacific Ocean twice to help people affected by World War II (or WWII for short)."

The last reason that Luke joined the Seagoing Cowgirls was because she got to be with animals. In paragraph 7 it states " Helping out on her aunt Katie's farm had prepared Luke for the hard work..." So that means that if she worked on a farm with a lot of animals, and she joins something with animals, that means she likes animals. Also in paragraph 1 it states " ... Don Reist invited her to go to Europe on a cattle boat." So that would mean that she wants to travel with animals in a baot or she wants to be in a boat filled with animals because she like animals (this story is kind of reminding me about Noah's Arch, you know the one with the boat filled with animals because there was a giant flood).

So those are the reasons why Luke desided to join the Seagoing Cowgirls. Remember she joined because she wanted to help countries that were damaged or destroyed in the World War II, it was an opportunity of a lifetime for her because she is a farm girl, and because she got to be with animals. That is why Luke joined the program.

original_text:
Luke was 18 years old. She just finished her high school graduation. Luke had two jobs working at a grocery store and at a bank, until her life cahnged.

Luke's friend Don Reist invited her to go to Europe on a cattle boat. Luke knew this was an opportunity of a lifetime. World War II just ended and a lot of countries needed help, so Luke and her friend started to help. The UNRRA hired the Seagoing Cowgirls to take care of all of the animals that would be on the boat. Luke and Don then signed up.

The cattle-boat trips were an unbelieveable opportunity for a small-town girl. Luke was happy that she was helping people but she was also really excited to see Europe and China. Luke also went to Venice, Italy and she even toured an excavated castle in Crete and marveled at the Panama Canal on her way to China.

Helping out on her aunt Katie's farm as a girl really helped and prepared her for this hard work that she is doing today. Then soon enough, Luke got a new job on the boat. Luke's job was check on all the animals every hour.

Then one night Luke's life almost ended. Luke was going to go see the captain but she slid down a slippery ladder on her backside. Luke almost flew overboard but a metal along the edge stopped her.

Luke had fun on board also. The cowgirls would play volleyball, baseball, table-tennis tournaments, fencing, boxing, reading, whittling, and games.

Luke was happy for what she has done. It made Luke more aware of people of other countries and their needs. That awareness always stayed with her. Luke saved peoples lives. Luke is a heroine.

World War II just ended and a lot of countries needed help, so Luke and her friend started to help. The UNRRA hired the Seagoing Cowgirls to take care of all of the animals that would be on the boat. Luke and Don then signed up.

The cattle-boat trips were an unbelieveable opportunity for a small-town girl. Luke was happy that she was helping people but she was also really excited to see Europe and China. Luke also went to Venice, Italy and she even toured an excavated castle in Crete and marveled at the Panama Canal on her way to China.

Helping out on her aunt Katie's farm as a girl really helped and prepared her for this hard work that she is doing today. Then soon enough, Luke got a new job on the boat. Luke's job was check on all the animals every hour.

Then one night Luke's life almost ended. Luke was going to go see the captain but she slid down a slippery ladder on her backside. Luke almost flew overboard but a metal along the edge stopped her.

Luke had fun on board also. The cowgirls would play volleyball, baseball, table-tennis tournaments, fencing, boxing, reading, whittling, and games.

Luke was happy for what she has done. It made Luke more aware of people of other countries and their needs. That awareness always stayed with her. Luke saved peoples lives. Luke is a heroine.]"

original_text: "There is an amazing program I joined called the 'Seagoing Cowgirls'. It is amazing." I told a group of people outside a restaurant. "Well, you can't convince us to join if you don't give us reasons." said a woman wearing blue overalls and a plaid shirt. To me, she looked a lot like a farmer. She looked just like a person the 'Seagoing Cowgirls' were looking for. "Let's see. Well, first of all, madam, if I may ask, are you a farmer?" I asked the woman wearing the overalls. "I sure am." she replied. "Do you enjoy taking care of horses, young cows, and mules?" I questioned her. "Of course I do. Why?" she asked. "The reason is, the 'Seagoing Cowgirls' are a group of people who go to take care of the horses, young cows, and mules that were shipped overseas. "Interesting," she said "Tell me more. "Other than helping people, I had the honor of seeing Europe and China. I also got to take a gondala ride in Venice, Italy, which is a city with streets of water." I added. "I always wanted to see Europe." the overalls woman said. "Well then, if you want to take care of animals and visit other places in the world, you should join the 'Seagoing Cowgirls!" I exclaimed. "I think I will!" the overalls woman said. "How do I sign up?" she asked. I gestured towards the sign up booth. "Right over there" I replied. As she walked to the booth I smiled with happiness. "Another job well done Luke." I whispered to myself.

Do you wonder why the program is good well some resons are they help countries recover there food supplies, there animals, and more. They also take care of a lot of animals like horses and young cows. They also take care of the mules that get ship overseas.

so they could help with the horses and mules the were shipped overseas.And then after Luke and Don heard about that they signed up to take a shot.

Then they started going out to sea. In August 1945, they went to New Orleans. And when they arrived in New Orleans it was August 14th. Did I tell you that Luke turned 18 before they got to Greece, which for her that means she could be drafted for military service.

Luke said that "The cattle boat trips were an unbelievable opportunity for a small town girl." She also said that helping people was the best part.And she said that she had the side benifit of seeing Europe and China.She saw lots of places like Italy and China and Europe. Even though she was working alot she still had some fun on the boat. She did fencing, boxing, reading, whittling. And games let her pass through time. She also played baseball and volleyball. And did I say that she couldn't work for a couple of days because of cracked ribs. Well I just told you and she was lucky to be alive.Luke even said she was lucky for the opportunity. She also said it made her more aware of other people in countrie and thier needs. She never gave up and she kept going even though sometimes it hurts.

original_text:
The reason for Luck Bomberher to join

the UNRRA program so she can help people,take care of the animals and to see different states like China and Europe.The letters UNRRA stand for United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration.Some of the animals she help was a horse,young cows and mules that were shipped overseas.

In the mounth August 1945,they had got a order to report to New Orleans,when they arrived August,14 luke said,the day the Pacific war ended.They got on the ship called the SS Charles W.wooster headed for Greece with 335 horses plus enough hay and oats to feed them.One of the most crazy thing is that she had turned 18 on the ship and before she got there.She wanted to be in the military but they told her to stay in the program UNRRA.BY the time she had been discharged in 1947 she made nine trips more than any Seagoing Cowgirl.

The cattle boat trips were unbelievable opportunity for the small town girl luke.She said besides helping people she saw China and Europe.But seeing Acropolis in Greece was special,she said. She said so taking a gondola ride in Venice,Italy,a city with sreeets of water.Luke also toured an exacavated castle in Crete and marveled at the Panama Canal on her way to China.Luke had to care for them animals and that keep her busy because it took them a month to get to China.She had to feed them and watered them three or two times a day.The dangeres part was night watch she was

coming down the ladder and slipped but a small metal along the edge stopped her from slidding. She said that she cant do that for a couple of days.Luke said that trip opened the world to her.Im grateful for the opportunity,she said.

I think that you should participate in the Seagoing Cowgirls program because ,It helps animals, you can have a great story to tell to your chilldren, and you can have fun. Well if that did'ent convinc you than, hears something that might, Luke Bomberger her self said "She found time to have fun on board, especially on return trips after the animals had beeen unloaded."The Cowgirls also played baseballand volleyball games in the empty holds where animals had been housed. Table-tennis tournaments, fencing, boxing, reading, whittling, and games also helped pass time." Before all of that Luke and the crew took care of the horses, young cows, and mules that were shiped overseas. When Luke and her friend Don they were sent right to work. Luke was a little ahead of her self becaus she helped out her aunt Katie on her farm as a girl , but her chalang was the dangerous seas.

Now Luke was in her early 20s and she was on her second night of wachman job, that ment that Luke had to check the animals every hour. It was a rainy night ,she was making her hourly report to the captin. on her way down she sliped down aladder on her back. Luke shot feet first to an opening on one side of the boat but a small strip of metal stoped her from falling into the dark, cold,tarorizing Atlantic.

She had crackend a couple of her ribs. In Lukes life time Luke had made nine trips the most of any Seagoing Cowgirl.

Being Sea going Cowgirl is much more Than a great time its an opportunity for you it giving you achance to see the word, and it shows you how much we are given in are country than other people around the world.

That awareness stays with you forever like it did with Luke Bomberger. After you do this you can tell stundents and others about what you did to help others ,and you might even make an impact on others. For being in her 20ntys Luke was a smart young woman for what she did.

So what chose are you going to make during your life , help ,or let animals die and people that need the food to servive and let them die to die?

Whats your chose?

original_text:
Luke Bomberger had a friend who asked her to tour Europe with her, she knew she couldn't turn it down.

World War II had just been in Europe, but was now over. Many comturies were left in ruins. These contries needed animals and livestock to survive. The UNRRA hired seagoing cowgirls to take care of the livestock on the boats when they were being shipped to a certain part of the world to another. Luke and her friend wanted to care and help, so they signed up for seagoing cowgirls program.

Luke had turned 18 upon the first trip, which meant she could be drafted for the army. Her draft amnagement company had learned she was in the seagoing cowgirls, and they told her to keep doing what she was doing, because it was a form of help.

Sometimesthe weather was bad upon the boats, and sometimes it was good. When it was bad, members upon the boat would participate in watching the storms. One night Luke had watch, she got into a bad accident that left her without work for a couple days due to broken ribs. When the weather was good, and all the chores were done for the day, the women upon the ship had time to play games or travel to see things. The animals are what kept Luke busy though.

When Luke had quit the seagoing cowgirls, she had successfully completed nine trips, the most trips a seagoing cowgirl has ever done, delivering animals to people in need of them.

A student submitted the following essay:

"[Essay Content: M-F152 / Luke Bomberger had a friend who asked her to tour Europe with her, she knew she couldn't turn it down.

World War II had just been in Europe, but was now over. Many comturies were left in ruins. These contries needed animals and livestock to survive. The UNRRA hired seagoing cowgirls to take care of the livestock on the boats when they were being shipped to a certain part of the world to another. Luke and her friend wanted to care and help, so they signed up for seagoing cowgirls program.

Luke had turned 18 upon the first trip, which meant she could be drafted for the army. Her draft amnagement company had learned she was in the seagoing cowgirls, and they told her to keep doing what she was doing, because it was a form of help.

Sometimesthe weather was bad upon the boats, and sometimes it was good. When it was bad, members upon the boat would participate in watching the storms. One night Luke had watch, she got into a bad accident that left her without work for a couple days due to broken ribs. When the weather was good, and all the chores were done for the day, the women upon the ship had time to play games or travel to see things. The animals are what kept Luke busy though.

When Luke had quit the seagoing cowgirls, she had successfully completed nine trips, the most trips a seagoing cowgirl has ever done, delivering animals to people in need of them.]"

original_text:
In this article the author tells us about Venus. She tells us that it is called the ¨Evening Star¨, that it is known as Earths ¨twin¨, and then she explains the attempts made to study and learn more about the planet. She also explains how those attempts were unsucsessful and that the planet is dangerous. But, despite the dangers she has presented to us, she explains that it is worth the danger. I dont personaly believe she did the best job explaining why she believed so and she definitly did not convince me to think the same.

The author never truely explained her claim that she thought exploring Venus was worth the risks and complications. For most of the artical she rambles on telling us about and explaining what was already found out about the planet. She never gave reasoning for believing we sould follow threw with trying to learn more about the planet. She only breifly told us her claim in the last paragraph, paragraph 8. It reads, ¨Striving to meet the challenge presented by Venus has value, not only because of the insight to be gained on the planet itself, but also because human curiosity will likely lead us into many equally intimidating endeavors.¨ She tells us that all we will get from risking our lifes is insite on a dangerous planet that we may not even have use for, and she states that we will be faced with more and or equally intimidating endeavors. It may just be my opinion but that does not seem like very convincing or valid reasons for putting lifes in danger.

I truely believe that the author of the artical, ¨The challenge of Exploring Venus¨ did not support her claim and what she believed very well let alone at all. All she gives us is two reasons that are not very valid and did not back them up or tell us why those reasons make a good point and sould make us think the same way. She did not tell us why we needed the information so badly that we should risk our lifes or even make the effort. I do not belive the author supported the idea or really stated her claim or what she belived. She needs more reasoning and explaining of what we would gain from this and how it would benifit us. She also would need more supporting details of what we need the information for and why.

Luke Bomberger had no idea how her life would change after gradutating high school. After graduating high school Luke Bombergers friend asked her if she wanted to go on a cattle boat. The reason they had the cattle boats was because World War II had just ended in Europe. After World War II ended many countries were crumbling. They needed the cattle boats for milk and meet to feed the people who had no home because of the war. I will list some reasons why she said yes.

A reason Luke Bomberger joined the cattle boat knew it would be fun. Another reason Luke Bomberger joind the Europe on a cattle boat trip was because she said "Luke couldn't say no. She knew it was an opportunity of a lifetime." Luke went on her first trip in August 1945 when she had orders to go to New Orleans. Luke and the other crew members arrived on the 14th of August, 1945. It took about 2 weeks to cross the atlantic ocean.

While Luke was on a trip to Greece she had her 18th birthday, Luke could've gone to the military, but her draft board told her to stay. By the time Luke was dicharged she had been on 9 cattle boat trips, that is the most of a sea going cowgirl.

original_text:
Have you ever been on a boat, well, Luke bomberger has. She was a part of a program called the Seagoing Cowgirls. She was a cowgirl that carried cattle and farm life from one place to another after the loss of many animals after World War II.

Today, she would encourage more people to join the Seagoing Cowgirls program because it is a very great thing to do and you can travel and visit many places you have never visited before.

When she was doing the job, Bomberer visited several places including, China, Europe, Greece, Italy, Crete, and Panama. Out of them all, Greece was the most special to her.

Luke knew what an amazing offer it was from the beginning and she knew she couldn't turn it down. And she would encourge you to join because if you ever thought abut joining the military they would accept you and let you serve by being a Seagoing Cowgirl.

In conclusion, you should become a Seagoing Cowgirl because it gives you opporunities, palces to travel to, experiencences , other jobs, and different culturers to endure and discover and make you a person who has seen and done amazing things that other people cant say they have done.

original_text:
Luke was had just graduated High School and had 2 part time jobs. One day Don, Luke's friend came to ask Luke if she wanted to travel on a cattle boat to Europe. Luke knew this was a once in a life time opportunity. Luke had said yes and at that moment she had just began an amazing adventure.

Luke had a very good experience that might have inspired the reader to do the same things. Luke was not only traveling in a boat to Europe but, she was also helping people get back to good shape because, world war 2 had just ended leaving them in bad shape. Students should be inspired because, Luke was helping people get back in good shape. People might also convinced to do the same thing Luke did.

Luke was having a lot of fun traveling around the world on a cattle ship. Luke knew this was an amazing opportunity in her life. Lukke herself had said that this was an amazing opportunity for a small town girl. She saw so many amazing things in the places she went. Luke had mentioned that she had been to Europe, China and Greece.

As Luke was on that cattle ship, she was helping people around the world get back to good shape, she was helping society. She was also bonding with animals, she was taking good care of animals. Most importantly it seemed like Luke was learning about the world and animals on this experience. Luke was experiencing how hard work felt. Luke, was really busy as they were crossing the Atlantic Ocean. She had to care of the animals by, feeding them, also giving them water and cleaning their stalls.

On her 2nd trip though she did have a diffcult time because, on a rainy night Luke was put as a watchman. She was supposed to check on the animals every hour. She had slipped down the ladder and got hurt. Because she couldn't work for a while, Luke found some ways to have fun on the ship. She and her friends played baseball and volleyball where the animals had stayed. After Luke had been discharged in 1947, Luke had made 9 trips(the most out of all seagoing cowgirls!)

Luke knew from the very beginning that this travel was the very beginning of an amazing adventure. Luke had learned alot over her travel. She had been to so many amazing places.She had been part of an amazing adventure to help people, that might have inspired\convinced to do the same thing.

original_text:
Luke Bomberger used to be an average teenager working two part-time jobs. Then her friend, Don Reist, came and asked her if she wanted to be a 'Seagoing Cowgirl', or one who helps bring livestock to war victims in Europe. Luke then took this as an opportunity of a lifetime and couldn't resist.

The Seagoing Cowgirls are a group of people who take care of livestock that were being shipped overseas to help the many that were devastated by the war in Europe. This livestock included young cows, horses, and mules. Shortly after Don and Luke found out about the Seagoing Cowgirls, they then both signed up. LIttle did Luke and Don know, this job had a lot of risks.

The Seagoing Cowgirls were a great part of an even greater orginization, the UNRRA, or the United Nations Relief and Rehibilitation Adminisrtation. This orginization was made up of 44 nations. This orginization also helped relieve and rehibilltate the devastated families of Europe. Luke knew what she was doing was a great cause, but did she know that going across the Atlantic and the Pacific oceans was a very risky thing. Luke could have had second thoughts about the risks that she was taking, but she wasn't doing it for herself, she was doing it for the people that needed her help.

original_text:
The author claims that studying Venus is worthy despite the many dangers. Throught the whole passage the author gives pros and cons about exploring Venus. She mentions facts that are good and bad about the planet, and trys to convince the reader that this idea to explore the planet, despite its dangers, is good.

In the first paragraph the author is trying to pull the readers attention in. She gives examples about Venus and explaines why she thinks it is worth being explored. The author states little facts about the planet, but is careful not to mention its dangerouse factors yet. She simple states that another name for Venus is the evening star. She also goes on to say that Venus is the second planet to the sun, and continues with these simpe facts.

As the author moves on through the story she starts to explain more of the cons of exploring this planet. She says that the temperature is well over eight hundred degrees Fahrenheit and aslo that the atmospheric pressure is 90 times greater than what we epxerience on Earth.

By telling the reader this information she is proving that even though she is listing all the dangers of doing this and exploring the planet, that she is going to convince you that this is worth exploring. The author goes on to say how powerful this planet is by saying that we have sent space crafts to Venus before and it hasen't lasted more than a couple of minutes, so why would we bother sending a human. She then explains what technolgy that we would be using to make this happen. She says that the computers we have now coulden't work because they are to delicate and can break easily. However we have very old computers avalible to us. The computers that helped us in World War two in the 1940s. She goes on to explain how her would work. At the end she says how she knows that this will be hard but that our travel on Earth should not be limited by dangers and doubts, but that we should explore these dangers.

I feel that the author did a very nice job. She stated what the problem was. She then continued to go on and explain the pros and cons of both sides. She gave many facts that suported her statment in the begining. She also was very organized with her thoughts and how she organized her writting.

original_text:
An argument that I have about Luke's point of view about the Seagoing Cowgirls program is when the artical said, " By the time she was discharged in 1947, Luke had made nine trips, the most of any Seagoing Cowgirl," and " It toook two weeks to cross the Atlantic Ocean from the eastern coast of the United States and a month to get to China". Who would ever want to take that long overseas.

Then, she also said," Caring for animals during the crossings kept Luke busy. They had to be fed and watered two or three times a day. Bales of hay and bags of oats had to be cleaned". I wouldn't want to work that hard overseas either.

Finally my last argument is when she said, " On her second trip, Luke served as night watchman. Her job was to check on all the animals every hour. One rainy night, after making her hourly report to the captain, she slid down a slippery ladder on her backside. Luke's heart raced as she shot feet first toward an opening on the side of the ship. A small strip of metal along the edge stopped her slide, keeping her from from flying overboard into the dark Atlantic. But she couldn't work for a couple of days because of cracked ribs. Who would ever want to go through that and get broken ribs. That is my argument to not be a Seagoing Cowgirl.

original_text:
Luke Bomberger had no idea her life would change after her high school graduation her friend Don Reist invited Luke to go to Europe on a cattle boat. She couldn't say no also, she knew this would be a opportunity of a lifetime. Don and Luke signed up for the UNRRA to help Europe and other countries that were left ruined. They headed for Greece with a cargo of 335 horses plus enough hay and oats to feed them.Luke turned 18 before arriving in Greece which ment she could be drafted for military service. By the time Luke was discharge in 1947,Luke had made nine trips- the most of any seagoing cowgirl.

Luke also toured an excavated castle in Crete and marveled at the Panama Canal on her way to China.Helping out on her aunt's farm as a girl had prepared Luke for hard work, not the dangers at sea. Luke also found time to have fun on board,especially on return trips after the animals had been unloaded. The cowgirl played baseball and volleyball in the empty holds where the animals were house. Table -tennis tournament, fencing, boxing, reading, whillting, and games also helped pass the time.

Being a seagoing cowgirl was much more than adventure for Luke Bomberger. It opened up the world for her.She said"I'm greatful for this opportunity", "It made me more aware of other countries and their needs.

"And that awareness stayed with her,leading her family to hostess a number of international students and exchange visitors for many years.

The Seagoing Cowgirls, which included Luke Bomberger, had helped many people due to the effect of the Word War II. The Cowgirls were known to help others, beat records from past Seagoing Cowgirls, and meeting new people.

The Cowgirls were a huge help after Word War II. They joined with 43 other nations to form UNRRA (The United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administratation), which was to help countries recover animals, food suplies, and more. The UNRRA also hired the "Seagoing Cowgirls" to take care of the young cows, mules, and horses that were shipped overseas.

When joining any club or, for example, the "Seagoing Cowgirls", records are to be broken. When Luke was 18, she had made nine trips, which was the most any Cowgirl has made. This was a big acomplishment for her, because it showed everybody what she could do.

Entering a club is a chance to meet new people. For example, when all the animals were unloaded, it was time to bring out your game side. Luke and the cowgirls would play baseball and volleyball games in the empty holds where the animals had been housed.

Joining the Seagoing Cowgirls is a wonderful experience, because you have the oppertunity to see new places, help others in need, and of course meet new people. The cowgirls are more than just Seagoing Cowgirls, their people helping people.

Exploration is key to a humans curiosity.Many people will indeed be anxious to explore something that is said to be impossible or dangerous because of curiosity."The Challenge of Exploring Venus" is a prime example. In this article the author states different reasons why it is worth stuying Venus depite the extreme dangers it brings.

One reason why the author of this article supports her ideas well is because she used statistics or in other words she used pathos.In paragraph five, she said"...a vehicle hovering over Venus would avoid the unfriendly ground conditions by staying up and out of their way."She mentioned the idea of NASA creating a "blimp-like" vehicle to fly over the Venusian landscape.Then she went on and entered her counterclaim by saying"...far above the planet can provide only limited insight on ground condition...,"therefore Venus would only be visible but not accesible and NASA would not be able to take samples of the planet.

Secondly,she states some facts about Venus itself.She added that "...Venus is the closests planet to Earth in terms of density and size."This is a good fact to add in to give the idea as to why NASA would choose to attempt studying Venus.Also she siad that"...humans have sent numerous spacecrafts to land on this cloud-draped world."This gives the idea that the study of Venus has already been attempted before and has unfortunately failed every single time.

Last but not least,in her conclusion she built a strong conclusion by mentionding in her opinion that"Our travels on Earth and beyond should not be limited by dangers and doubts but should be expanded to meet the very edges of imaginataion and innovation." This can be used for both life and NASA continuing on trying and trying until they succesfully study Venus.

In conclusion, the author supported her ideas well in the article. She supported her idead with statistics from NASA theirselves and she gave facts about Venus. She also included her counterclaims. Over all she gave a well informend and structures article.

original_text:
Seagoing Cowgirls need more members. The benefits of becoming a Seagoing Cowgirl are visiting exciting places, becoming more aware of people who need help, a young woman might not get drafted into the army, and there is ways that the girls find to have fun after the cattle has been unloaded.

Being able to travel all across the world is a benefit of being a Seagoing Cowgirl. Many take tours and go sightseeing at each destination they arrive at.

A Seagoing Cowgirl will become more aware of the people in need that are around them every single day. Luke Bomberger was a Cowgirl and after she was discharged her family hosted a good number of exchage visitors and international students.

Another reason someone might join the Seagoing Cowgirls program is that they might not get drafted in the army if they are the correct age of 18. They army would see that they are already helping out in the war. They would be helping in the war by bring cattle to the countries that lost most of their cattle and fields.

After the cattle had been unloaded all of the girl on board the ship would play baseball and volleyball in the hold where the cattle had been. Whittling, reading, table-tennis, fencing, boxing, and other games were used to pass the time.

Being a Seagoing Cowgirl let the girls visit exciting places and become more aware of people who need help. A young woman might not get drafted into the army and there is ways that the girls find to have fun after the cattle has been unloaded. All of these reasons lead up to joining the Cowgirls as soon as possible.

She got to see unique things, participate in the recovery of other countries during the war, and it impacted her life forever. Other people who want to help the world should definitely participate in the Seagoing Cowgirls program.

The first reason why other people should participate in the Seagoing Cowgirls program is because they would get to help recover other countries from the war.

The text states, by the time she was discharged in 1947, Luke had made nine trips-the most of any Seagoing Cowgirl. On all of those trips, Luke was helping deliver cattle to other countries to recover their food and animal supply. Many countries were in ruins and they needed the help that the Seagoing Cowgirls provided.

Next, more people should participate in the Seagoing Cowgirls program because they would get to see and visit many unique and interesting places around the world. The text states, Luke was able to see the Acropolis in Greece. The text also states, on her many trips, Luke got to take a gondola ride in Venice, Italy. Luke also toured an excavated castle in Crete and marveled at the Panama Canal on her way to China.

Finally, others should participate in the Seagoing Cowgirls program because it will change their lives. The text states, after her great adventures as a Seagoing Cowgirl, Luke's family was lead to hostess a number of international students for many years. The text also states, this experience opened up the world to Luke. Luke also got to bond with new people on board the SS Charles W. Wooster. She got to spend lots of time with them including times of playing volleyball, baseball, fencing, and many more activities to help pass time.

This shows why more people should participate in the Seagoing Cowgirls program. They would get to see unique things, participate in the recovery of other countries during the war, and impact thier lives forever.

original_text:
The Seagoing Cowgirls is a great program, but being one is better. The cowgirls go to fun places like China and Europe. But it is also a lot of hard work too, Luke had to care for the animals during crossings, the animals had to be fed and watered two to three times a day, bales of hay and bags of oats had to be pulled up from the lower holds of the ship.

After the animas had been unloaded the cowgirls would had some freetime to play volleyball and baseball. They also play table-tennis tournaments, fencing, boxing to help pass the time. When they have a long trip and a lot of freetime they visit places, like when Luke toured an excavated castle in Crete, and marveled at the Panama Canal on her way to China.

Seagoing Cowgirls could go basically anywhere. They went to China, Europe, Greece, and Crete. At the age of 18 Luke could be drafted for military service, but since she was on a cattle-boat trip, they told her she could do that for her service. So if your a Seagoing Cowgirl it counts as being in the military service.

My conclusion is being a Seagoing Cowgirl can "open someones eyes" to the needs of animals. Like Luke said, "It made me more aware of people of other countries and their needs." Seagoing Cowgirls are very persistent, and if you like animals you should join this program. Because when Luke fell and slid on the ship, she almost fell off because she was helping the animals. And when Luke cracked her ribs on the ship, she didn't quit, she kept being a Seagoing Cowgirl, and continued to help the animals. The Seagoing Cowgirls care more about the animals than they do themselves, and that is great. Because it might be hard work but the animals need all the help they can get.

original_text:
In the article "The Challenge of Exploring Venus", the author believes that studying the planet Venus would be a rewarding endeavor. The author presents her claim and supports it very well through the knowledge she already has about the planet, the knowledge that the exploration of Venus might uncover, and persuasion through relating to her readers. This allows for the author to very clearly and precisely get her point across to those who might read the article. It also creates a strong way for the author to connect to her readers.

When the author uses the knowledge that she already has about Venus, she is trying to convey that what information we have on Venus is already important. In Paragraph 4, the author presents the idea that Venus "may well once have been the most Earth-like planet in our solar system". When the author introduces this concept, she also describes the surface of Venus to be "rocky" and "includes similar features such as valleys, mountains, and craters,". Becuase the author presents the idea that Venus might have been like Earth and then goes on to describe this, she strongly supports her claim of how rewarding studying Venus could be. She is also trying to spark an interest in her readers regarding the study of Venus.

In Paragraph 6, the author suggests that researchers need to get closer to the ground.

When she says "researchers cannot take samples...from a distance", she is urging scientists to find ways to get closer to Venus's surface. To support this she also presents that scientists "cannot take samples of rock, gas, or anything else" without getting closer. She uses the curiousity of woman to lure them into what she wants them to. This proves to be strong support for her main claim. This also leads right into the persuasion aspect of her support.

The author uses persuasion throughout the article, but in Paragraph 8 it is used excessively. Near the end of the paragraph, she introduces the idea that "Our travels on Earth and beyond should not be limited by dangers and doubts...". When she uses "should not" in that sentence, she is adding a strong opinion to her conclusion. In doing so, her opinion also contributes to the persuasion factor. This allows for her to call out to the reader individually and emotionally affect them. Using persuasion made way for the author to support her claim very well and influence the reader to think the same way as her.

Overall, the author has a very well thought-out way of supporting her claim that studying Venus would be a worthy persuit, despite the dangers. The author hits the brick wall head on by first presenting the knowledge she already has. This allows for the readers to have a little bit of foreground to play on. Then, she introduces the knowledge that could be gained by studying the planet, giving the readers a clear-cut example of how studying Venus might present important information. Finally, she includes persuasion, making it possible to influence the readers one by one. In conclusion, the author supports the claim, studying Venus is a worthy persuit despite the dangers it presents, very well.

If you are the tip of person that likes to travel this is the purfected jod for you. But if you get sea sike this is a taribble job for you. original_text:
I think people should participate in the Seagoing Cowgirls program because it's a fun and exciting program.

The text states,"The cattle-boat trips were and unbelievable opportunity for a benefiy of seeing Europe and China."

The text also states,"But seeing the Acropolis in Greece was special, she says.

So was taking a gondola ride in Venice, Italy, a city with streets of water."

Another reason to join the program is you get to learn a lot of interesting stuff.

The text states,"Luke served as a night watchman.

Her job was to check on all the animals every hour."

The text also states,"But being a Seagoing Cowgirl was much more than an adventure for Luke Bomberger.

It opened up the world to her.

One final reason to join the program is because if you like dangerous stuff the program is dangerous.

The text states,"Helping out on her aunt Katie's farm as a girl had prepared Luke for hard work, but not for the dangers at sea.

Her job was to check on all the animals every hour.

One rainy night, after making her hourly report to the captain, she slid down a slippery ladder on her backside.

Luke's heart raced as she shot feet first toward an opening on the side of the ship.

A small strip of metal along the edge stopped her slide, keeping her from flying overboard into the dark Atlantic.

She was happy to be alive.

But she couldn't work for a couple of days because of craked ribs."

Those reasons are why you should join the Seagoing Cowgirls program.

original_text:
Luke said she grew up on an farm with her aunt so she wanted to help the animals. After World War 2 Luke wanted to help the countries recover by bringing food supplies and animals. Luke loved animals because when she was younger she had lived on a farm. So when she heard UNRRA is hirring Seagoing Cowgirls to take care of Horses,Cows,and Mules she and her friend Don signed up. This to Luke this was an opportunity of a life time.

Luke got on an boat called SS Charles W. Wooster and there were 335 Horses plus hay and oats to feed the Horses. When Luke was 18 she could be drafted to be in the military but when they heard she was on a cattle boat trip they told Luke to stay. In 1947 Luke made nine trips the most out of any Seagoing Cowgirl. Luke said "Besides helping people, I had the side benefit of seeing Europe and China. But seeing the Acropoils in Greece was special,"she says.

If you get to go on this trip you would be busy but you would have so much fun. Also if you like caring for people and animals you would be perfect for this journey. Another reason is if you like travling on a boat and don't get sea sick you should try being a Seagoing Cowgirl or girl. Not only that but you could become famous just for helping people. Then again you should always help people. Luke went would you?

original_text:
In this passage we see Luke's experience as a Seagoing Cowgirl.

Luke shows us how being a Seagoing Cowgirl gave her awareness for other people. She also shows us the many impotant things to learn from this job.

First, while being a Seagoing Cowgirl Luke learned to take care of many of the animals.

She fed them and gave them water.

These actions, in turn, helped many people that were suffering.

Second, caring for the animals taught Luke to be responsible and to be a hard worker.

In the passage Luke said she had to make sure she fed the animals, give them water every day, and clean the stalls.

She also said ha had to be a night guard and check on the animals every hour to make sure everything was okay.

Next, other than taking care of the animals and doing different work, Luke also got to see new things and have fun.

She said she saw China, Europe, the Acropolis in Greece, an excavated castle in Crete,and the Panama Canal.

She also went on a gondola ride in Venice, Italy.

Even on the boat Luke had fun.

She and the other cowgirls played baseball and volleyball games, had tournaments, and did other enjoyable things.

Finally, Luke saw people that were hurting and that needed her help.

Luke said '' I'm grateful for the opportunity,'' and that '' It made me more aware of people...''

Because of the Seagoing Cowgirls program, Luke helped many others, even after she was discharged from the program.

The Seagoing Cowgirls program was a eye opening adventure for Luke.

It can also be a life changing experience for other people too.

They can learn lessons and help people just like Luke did.

It may also change their outlook on life. They may want to do more to help others in need, rather than just helping themselves.

original_text: Luke Bomberger works at two jobs and has a busy life style. She works at the grocery store and at the bank. Don, her friend asked if she wanted to go to Europe on a cattle boat. Luke didn't know what to say, because it was an opportunity of a life time. So she decided to go, they were to go overseas to take care of horses, young cows, and mules. In 1945 they recieved there orders to New Orleans and they arrived August 14, 1945. Eventually, they headed to Greece with 335 horses also with eniugh hay and oats to feed them. Luke turned the age 18 before arriving to greece which meant she could be ready to participate for military service. When they learned she was on a cattle boat they told me to keep doing what I was doing. Luke had made 9 trips, more than any Seagoing Cowgirl ever. It was an amazing opportunity for Luke, she loved visiting ancient things. Luke didn't just have to me stuck in a boat with horses she got to also go out and adventure. It took 2 weeks to cross the Alantic Ocean, from the eastern coast of the United States. Also another month to get china, this seems like hard work. But the animals kept Luke busy, they had t be fed and watered two or three times a day. Bales of hay had to be pulled from ship to feed them. Luke had some experience by helping on Katies farm as a girl. On lukes second trip at a Seagoing Cowgirl, she was to be night watchman her had to check on the animals every hour. A rainy night she had to go down a ladder, her feet slipped then a small trip of metal caught her from tumbling of the boat. She was happy to be alive, even with a few cracked ribs so she couldnt work for a couple days. Luke always had fun on board though. She got to play games which would make time go faster. Games such as volleyball, baseball, tennis and more. Being a Seagoing cowgirl wasnt just an adventure she had fun to and the world open up to her. It made her aware of many opportunities. As you can tell Luke has a busy life with everything going on but she enjoys being a part of many things. Luke is glad her friend Don let her go on this trip.

But the animals kept Luke busy, they had t be fed and watered two or three times a day. Bales of hay had to be pulled from ship to feed them. Luke had some experience by helping on Katies farm as a girl. On lukes second trip at a Seagoing Cowgirl, she was to be night watchman her had to check on the animals every hour. A rainy night she had to go down a ladder, her feet slipped then a small trip of metal caught her from tumbling of the boat. She was happy to be alive, even with a few cracked ribs so she couldnt work for a couple days. Luke always had fun on board though. She got to play games which would make time go faster. Games such as volleyball, baseball, tennis and more. Being a Seagoing cowgirl wasnt just an adventure she had fun to and the world open up to her. It made her aware of many opportunities. As you can tell Luke has a busy life with everything going on but she enjoys being a part of many things. Luke is glad her friend Don let her go on this trip.]"

original_text:
The author does not support her idea well because she has little of evidence to back up the claims that she made. These claims were that Venus could be useful because of how close it is and she called it a challenge for human curiosity. Neither of the claims she made were to vbalid becauise she would go off topic, provide little evidence, and would talk about the benefits of Venus but not say what they were.

When she claimed that Venus is useful because of how close it is and said " ...Venus can sometimes be our nearest option for a planetary visit, a crucial consideration given the long frames of space travel." and then said " The value of returning to Venus seems indisputable..." so she made a claim saying that it is a good thing to go to venus but the right after said the value is indisputable but never gave any evidence of why its so good to go to. Then she also claimed that it has value in over coming, that it is a challenge for human curiosity. This is a bad claim because she did not have much evidence or reason to back up going to Venus so she said " Striving to meet the challenge presented by Venus has value, not only because of the insight to be gained on the planet itself, but also because human curiosity will likely lead us into many equally intimidating endeavors." This claim would be much better if she actually listed any good benefits from Venus. Also through the text the author seems to either run out of things to support her claim or she went off topic because she started to talk about what NASA is doing and planning to do to explore Venus like " NASA's possible solution to the hostile conditions would be to allow scientist to float above the fray." She would say thing of what people might be able to do to explore Venus with its hostile conditions but she still never said what could be discovered while exploring.

I don't disagree on her point but how she executes getting it across to the audience does not work. If she provided any solid evidence on what could be learned or discovered on Venus like technology or new elements then it would bring more people behind this idea. But that still does not change the fact that her claims of Venus is useful for future visits and its a good challenge for human curiosity, are not valid and she does not to a good jobs of supporting her claims.

original_text:
Luke Bomberger was working at the grocery store and a bank when her friend Don Reist came up to her and invited her to go on a cattle boat to Europe. Luke finally said yes when she knew that this was an opportunity of a lifetime. When World War ll was over in Europe they needed people to go to countries to help recover their food supplies, animals, and more,44 nations joined together to form UNRRA. Luke and Don signed up to go on the ship to Europe. They had to be "Seagoing Cowgirls" to take care of the horses, young cows, and mules that were shipped overseas.

Luke's participation in the Seagoing Cowgirls allowed her to experience going to alot of places and exploring them. She went to Greece-with a cargo of 335 horses plus enough hay and oats to feed them." But seeing the Acropolis in Greece was special,"she says. "Besides helping people , I had the side benefit of seeing Europe and China. Luke also toured an excavated castle in Crete and marveled at the Panama Canal on her way to China.

Luke had a fun time seeing all these places, you can tell by how well she explaines them. By the way she explaines this, she should really be encouraging people to join the Seagoing Cowgirls program. She makes it sound like it is alot of fun. Luke also found time to have fun on board, the cowgirls played baseball and volleyball games in the empty holds where animals had been housed. By being a Seagoing Cowgirl, Luke says that it makes her more aware of people of other countries and their needs."And that awareness stayed with her, leading her family to hostess a number of international students and exchange visitors for many years.

Have you ever wanted to help people during war without joining the military well you should join the Seagoing Cowgirls program. The Seagoing Cowgirls program is where you get on a boat with other people and go to far places to get animals.

The Seagoing Cowgirls program is a good way to help other country so there country's people can survive after war and other causes. On the Seagoing Cowgirls program you can meet new people, and see new places and structures. You can also take animals from one country to another to give one country animals so they can make food so they all don't starve. You can also help make peoples lives better after war and acomplish great things. Just like Luke Bomberger who was just a average town girl then she joined the Seagoing Cowgirls program because her friend then she became a heroine.

The Seagoing Cowgirls program was created by the UNRRA (the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration). The UNRRA was created during World War 2 in 1945 to help country's effected by World War 2 by destruction. The UNRRA helps by getting soldiers to help fight. They also search for food and animals. The Seagoing Cowgirls program helps by getting horses,young cows, and mules. The Seagoing Cowgirls program headed to Greece with a cargo of 335 and enough hay and oats to feed them.

Joining the Seagoing Cowgirl is a good idea if you want to help country's just like Luke Bombberger did by brining animals you can see different places and meet new people.

original_text:
In the article, "The Challenge of Exploring Venus," the narrator tells us why NASA is struggling so much to explore the planet of Venus, what's so hard about it, and what their plan is.

The author believes that studying Venus is a "worthy pursuit despite the dangers it presents." The author supports her idea very well by proving many good points and using factual evidence.

The author supports her idea by proving good points and using evidence. You can tell she is sincere about this and would like for the scientists to try and further explore Venus and its commodoties. For example, in paragraph 8, she talks about how our travels on Earth and beyond should not be limited by dangers and doubts. This is a very reasonable statement, and proves that she actually has a reason to want Venus to be explored. Also in paragraph 8, the author says, "Striving to meet the challenge presented by Venus has value, not only because of the insight to be gained on the planet itself, but also because human curiosity will likely lead us into many equally intimidating endeavors." This quote supports the authors idea because she is giving an ethical reason about why she wants scientists to create the technology to be able to put humans on Venus. She is explaining to the readers why she wants this to take place, and by giving her opinion, it automatically supports her and her idea.

The author does many things to help support her idea throughout this article. She is very opinionated about why she wants there to be people on Venus. The author support her idea very well by proving many good points and using factual evidence.

original_text:
The Seagoing Cowgirls is a program that people recommend you join and this is why. Luke Bomberger is trying to convince others to join the Seagoing Program because you get to help peolpe in need,experience new things,and visit tourist sites in different areas.

First,you should join this because you get to help peolpe in need. Luke helped people after World War II was over in Europe recover their food supplies, animals,and much more. Another way that she helped is she took care of people's horses,young cows,and mules that were shipped overseas by herself.

Secondly, you can experience new things. Luke first took care of the animals on a ship and after that she was a night watchman. On the boat she got to play baseball and volleyball games in the empty holds where animals had been housed with the cowgirls. She also got to do table-tennis tournaments, boxing, fencing, reading, whittling, and other games.

Lastly,you an visit tourist sites. Luke got to visit an excavated castle in Crete and marveled at the Panama Canal on her way to China. She also got to take a gondola ride in Venice,Italy. Lastly,on her way she got to see the Acropolis in Greece.

Now you can see why you should join the Seagoing Cowgirls. From helping people in need, experiencing new things, to visiting tourist sites. Now you know what program you can join after hgih school, in the future.

original_text:
You will like to join the Seagoing Cowgirls because you will take care of the animals that are on the boat. You will get to sightsee and go to different countries that you have never been before. After the animals leave the boat you get to do things on the boat like reading, Table-tennis tournaments, boxing, and more fun activites. Everyday you maybe need to go to deliver the animals to a new country and you will get to feed them and take care of them. This girl named Luke graduatied and her life changed after she said yes to go on a cattle boat.

First, Luke graduated high school and she had two part-time jobs one at the grocery store and one at the bank her friend Don invited her on a cattle boat to go to Europe she said yes and she knew it was an opportunity of a lifetime. When it was nineteen fourty-five World War two was over in Europe and the UNRRA hired Seagoing Cowgirls to take care of the animals that were shipped over sea. Luke and Don singed up to be Seagoing Cowgirls and in August nineteen fourty-five they received their orders to report to New Orleans and Luke says, "We arrived August fourteen the day the pacific war ended." so they both got their seaman's papers and boarded the SS Charles W. Wooster, that was headed for Greece. Luke turned eightteen which meant she could be drafted for the military service. By the time she was discharged in 1947, Luke made nine trips which was the most of any Seagoing Cowgirl.

In conclusion Luke was a good Seagoing Cowgirl but, she was not working for a couple of days because she cracked her ribs on a rainy night. Luke was knowed for making the most trips that a Seagoing Cowgirl has ever made. Luke had a total of sixteen times that she croosed the Atlantic Ocean and the Pacific Ocean twice to help people affected by World War two. Luke was a nice caring woman who help on the ship and the people. Luke opened up the world to her and had a grateful opportunity that made her more awareof the people of the other countries and their needs.

In the story "A Cowgirl Who Rode the Waves" is about a woman named Luke. Luke first started out working two part-time jobs at a grocery store and at a bank. Then her friend Don invited Luke to go on a cattle boat ride to Europe, but Luke couldn't say no.

Then the reason Luke started to work with the "Seagoing Cowgirls" because she wanted to help the people with their cattles, horses, and mules. Also to help countries recover their food supples, animals, and more, 44 nations joined to help to form UNRRA. Luke also join to travel across the ocean and se new places too.

Then Luke work hard to feed the cattle, horses, and mules twice or three times a day, Luke started to work hard by bring up bales of hay and bring bags of oats from the lower holds of the ship to feed the cattle, horses, and mules everyday, and cleaning the stalls for the aniamls to comfortable when the animals are on the ship. Then on one rainy night after Luke made her hour report to the captain. She slipped on the leader and landed on her backside, but she was stopped by a small strip of metal on the edge to keep her from flying overboard. Luke broke her ribs and could not work for a couple days to her engary.

In conclusion Luke and other people had a hard life during the year that they had, but they still had a good life during the year with their families and friend that are there to support you no matter what happenes during those year they had together.Also you should always work hard to complete your goals in life like Luke did in the story. When Luke completed her goals she got the best out it and she was happy all her life and her dream came ture to be a "Seagoing Cowgirl" because she worked hard with the cattle, horses, and mules by getting them to places the animals need to go.

original_text:
The Sea Going cowgirl may interest many people.

You may wonder why.

Lots of people all around the world are suffering from world war 2.

You may want to help them.

This program will let you do that for many different counteries.

If you were to join this program you would sail on a ship.

It may contain animals,food,and other helpful items. Many things were destroyed in world war 2.

Including homes,animals,and people.

All this stuff will change that.

You will save countless lives.

China,Europe,and many other places were destoryed because of world war 2.

Luke is deffinetley a heroine because of her bravery.

She even got her ribs hurt on the ship.

Many people would quit after an accident like that,she didn't.

She kept doing her best to help those people that were suffering.

In conclusion,I think Luke is a heroine.

I know many people would say no to helping other people because of the danger.

Others may do it in a heartbeat.

If you don't,I understand.

If you do, then you will be a big heroine just like Luke.

original_text:
Luke Bomberger is a who had started working in a grocery story and a bank, just when she got out of high school. Once she went on this trip to Europe with her friend Don Reist. Luke started enjoying going to oversea trips, even though she knew it would take a long time. Have you ever wanted to take an oversea trip? If your answer is yes we would like you to come and sign up for The United Relief and Rehabilitation Adminstration. Its for SEagoing Cowgirls that are willing to take care of horses, youngcows, and mules that are shipped overseas.

When you go through the proccess of going on the trip, don't get nervous. Luke Bomberger was a confident woman to go on her journey with her best friend and was never really afraid. Every time you ride on that boat you feel more a live, which is a good thing. All you have to do is believe in yourself and you can do anything! Taking care of animals is another thing to, if you absolutely love animals than of course you might want to join. Especially if you are a farmer girl.

Going on the journey made Luke feel alive, and it should make you feel alive if you think you are going to join the club that takes you overseas. I know all the women loved to go on that trip to take care of many farm animals, especially if you do that your everyday life. When Luke was on that trip she loved it, she first(1st) went to New Orleans for the trip. They got there the day the Pacific war ended , on August 14th. On her first (1st) trip the crew she was with ended up with 335 horses on the cargo, and had enough to feed everyone including the women on the ship.

The story of Luke Bomberger is probably not urging you yet, but when Luke was official 18 she knew that she could join military. Then she thought I still love seagoing trips, so I'm going to stick with it so she did. Do you see how motivated Luke was to join the Club of UNRRA. Luke already taken a total of nine(9) trips and she was proud of it. Luke couldnt imagine her life without the trips she wouldn't have gone on so she stayed on going with it and she was confident in her choice.

Not just that but Luke got to visit other countries such as China and European countries, such as Venice, Italy. She also got to help people all over the world. She was so proud of what she did and so full of joy. Luke oncer got hurt on one (1) of her journeys. While Luke was checking on the anoimals on a very rainy night she slipped and fell but luckly there was a small piece of metal that protected Luke from flying off the deck into the Atlantic Ocean, but thanks to that small piece of metal she was saved.

So ask yourself do you want to join the UNRRA club(united Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Adminstration). If you do make sure on your descions that you want to do it. Anything is possible for anyone! If it was possible for Luke Bomberger than its possible for you! So sign up now if you want to be a success like Luke Bomberger! Keep in mind that you can see animals , help people, and you can also visit places you have never visited in your whole life.

original_text:
In a Cowgirl who Rode the waves , the author talks about the Seagoing Cowgirls program. Not only does this program help victims , but it can save many cities that would soon start a war. Luke went over the Atlantic Ocean 16 times to help WW2 victims and help their community grow and rebuild their city. There are more than 1,000 victims in each world war that happens and just imagine how many animals were killed too.

One way you could join the Seagoing Cowgirls would be to simply sign up for it, since Luke claims that she just signed up ,as stated in the text. You could also join the UNRRA and get the opportunity to get to choose every branch that could help victims in need. Even though Luke signed up to help the Cattle boat, she got to go sight seeing in China, Acroppolis , Venis,Italy and the Panama Canal.

Out of all of the time, Luke was on the Cattle boat , but in the text it states that she did the same things on her Aunts farm, but did not help her at sea. One day a bad storm hit and she landed by the animal pens and landed on a pice of metal , she could not work for a few days because of her broken ribs. She was happy to be alive but when the animals were shipped the crew would play lots of fun games. She had done this 9 times to and from where they were getting dropped off at. Also, she crossed the Atlantic Ocean 16 times.

After doing this job she helped get awareness of everything and why other people needed to join . She helped most victims with getting a new home and rebuilding their city. Luke enjoyed doing this job and loved playing with the crew after the animals were loaded. For Luke this was more than a job. After all she had to have a little adventure , right?

In conclusion , Luke loved her job. It was as it was all an adventure. The text states that it opened a new world to her. After that she raised more awareness. All i know is that she will , Survive !

original_text:
Luke Bomberger became a Seagoing Cowgirl she helps people whose lives had been affected by World War ll. Luke became a Seagoing

Cowgirl because she knew it was an opportunity of a lifetime, as she says in paragraph one. Luke also wanted to help others who had been affected by World War ll.

Luke crossed the Atlantic Ocean sixteen times and the Pacific Ocean twice, to help countries recover their food supplies, animals, and much more as it says in paragraph two. Even though it was a long journey across the oceans and the waters were rough Luke loved being a Seagoing Cowgirl and she loved to help the people.

Some people would probably refuse to go to another country that had just been through war some people would say it was to risky and unsafe well it is, some people might say that it is too dangerous to cross the ocean well it is but Luke felt that these were things that she needed to do and is something that is important to her.

Luke also got to visit many great places in between her journeys, she got to see many different places such as the Panama Canal on her way to China in paragraph five Luke says that "seeing the Acropolis in Greece was special" and "so was taking a gondola ride in Venice , Italy a city with streets of water. Luke thought that it was all so great.

But some people might say that they wouldnt go there because once again it's just too dangerous or that if they wanted to go there then they definetly not go on a boat and they would much more want to fly there. Well once again that is their opinion and Luke was happy the way that she went and was happy that she could see it and that she go to experience the jouney.

In conclusion Luke loves being a Seagoing Cowgirl she loves all the sights, all the help that she can give to these other people, and that she could have this opportunity in life.

You should really join the Seagoing Cowgirls because they have lots of fun even though it might seem scary to be on a boat with horses then yes but it is actually pretty safe. If you want to see the world or some parts of it then sign up and come join us because we go everywhere you can imagine like China, New Zealand, and Crete. She also said it made her more aware of people of other countries and there needs. In the middle of the story people realized that people, animals, and more looked dried out, so 44 nations had joined to form UNRRA and hired "Seagoing Cowgirls."Luke and Don had signed up for it, knowing that they were going to help animals. When they had arrived from taking the animals to New Orleans the day the Pacific War had ended. They had 335 horses plus enough oats and hay to feed them. Luke had recently turned 18 before arriving to Greece. She had made 9 trips before being discharged.

I think that thanks to Don, Luke had gotten a great job just for her. I also think that Luke enjoyed the buisness she was in and what she was doing. Don is very encouraging, helpful, nice, and thanks to all of that she had gotten her friend,Luke, a job. Luke had later began helping her auntie on the farm and it prepared her for hard work. This story or passage is something that I would read again and again. It is very interesting and different. original_text:
Have you ever tried becoming a seagoing cowgirl? If not, I suggest that you consider joining the program. The job of a seagoing cowgirl is to take care of horses, young cows, and mules which are sent overseas to people that need them. While being in the Seagoing Cowgirl program, there are many positive things such as being able to experience adventures, visiting many unique places, and having the opportunity to help people in need.

A Seagoing Cowgirl is able to experience many adventures. When Luke was a seagoing cowgirl, she had the chance of experiencing a storm while at sea. Think about how exciting and adventurous that would be! Also Luke says that she found time to have fun on board, especially once all the animals were taken care of or unloaded. The cowbobys would then play baseball and volleyball games in the empty holds, or set up different sporting tournements. Experiencing a storm at sea and playing many fun games on board are just two examples of the many adventures that could take place as a seagoing cowgirl.

If you are a seagoing cowgirl, you not only have adventures but you also can see and visit many unique places that an average person wouldn't have the opportunity to see or experience. In Luke's nine years as a seagoing cowgirl, she was able to see and experience some pretty interesting things in Europe and China. She specifically saw the Acropolis in Greece, and thought that that experience was very special. On top of seeing the Acropolis, she also was able to take a gondola ride in Venice, Italy. There would also be many more places to go and people to see.

The main reason for becoming a seagoing cowgirl would be to help people in need. Luke specifically helped people affected by World War II. The people affected by World War II needed food, clothing, animals, and more. Luke helped with the animals. Luke states that she was very grateful for the opportunity of becoming a seagoing cowgirl so she could help people in need. She says that it made her "more aware of people of other countries and their needs."

Becoming a seagoing cowgirl is a great experience and very beneficial. Luke says, "the cattle-boat trips were an unbelievable opportunity for a small-town girl."

This evidence from the text explains why you would get hurt on the job "One rainy night,after making her hourly report to the captain she slid down a slippery ladder on her backside. Atlantic."

In conclusion, I think both of these paragraphs show some pro's and con's of becoming a seagoing cowgirl. Now let me ask you again, Have you ever wanted to be a seagoing cowgirl?

original_text:
Luke is a nice gal who lived in a small-town so she helped the people in Europe because her friend don had told her that after the world war 2 europe and many other countries were left in ruins.Europe was left with nothing so to help these countries had to recover their food supplies,animals,and more, 44 nations had joinned together to form UNRRA [ the united nations relief and rehabiitation administration].

UNRRA hired seagoing cowgirls to take care of the horses,young cowgirls,and mules that were shipped overseas.

So lukes friend told her all about it and she told her if she would go to europe of corse luke coudn't say no so luke and don signed up for the seagoing cowgirls so they could help europe with all the stuff they needed.In Agust 1945,they received their orders from new orleans.

They arrived in August 14,luke said that the day the pacificwar ended.they got their seaman's paper and boarded the ss charles w.wooster,and had heeded for greece with cargoof 335 horsesand enough hay and goats to feed them.

Europe was sure geeting helped a hole buch it was geting better and wasn't in ruins that much that was a lot of help it was geeting.luke had turned 18 when she and don had arrived in greece wich meant she would be drafted to military service wich would also she the military with soldiers.

Luke had made nine trips-the most of any seagoing cowboythe cattle-boat trips were unbelievevable opportunity for a samall-town girl

they wouldn't believe it that she would be able to do that kind of thing, but she was still able to do it and she helped europe.

original_text:
Luke Bomberger crossed the Atlantic Ocean 16 times and the Pacific Ocean twice to help people affected by Word War ll. In this passage there is a lot of good things and bad things about being Seagoing Cowgirl, like what fears you have to overcome,what jobs you do, and how long you have to do it and what kind of fun they have.

To begin with,you have to be very brave to become a Seagoing Cowgirl.

To become a Seagoing Cowgirl you can't be scared of water or being on a boat for a long time. One day when Luke was on night watchman it was very rainy.

When she was going to make her hourly report to her captin she fell on a slippery ladder and cracked her ribs.

Next, is what jobs you do to become a Seagoing Cowgirl. If you are a Seagoing Cowgirl you have help a lot of people and animals.

On the way across the Atlantic Ocean, Luke's boat picked up some animals. Luke was incharge of feeding them and give them water 2 to 3 times a day. Also she had to clean up after the animals.

Last, is how long you have to be on the ship and what fun you can have.

When Luke had to cross the Atlantic Ocean it took her ship 2 weeks to get across. After the animals got unloaded, the other Seagoing Cowgirls got to have some fun. The cowgirls played baseball and volleyball games where the animals had been housed.

Tabel-tennis tournaments, fencing, boxing, reading, whittling, and games also helped pass time.

To sum up my thoughts, being a Seagoing Cowgirl isn't that bad.

In the passage there is a lot of good and bad things about Seagoing Cowgirls in the fears you have to overcome, how long you have to do it and the fun you can have, and the jobs you have to do. In the future, I hope we can have more people become Seagoing Cowgirls.

I think that Luke Bomberg would want you to join the Seagoing Cowgirls because you get the oppertunity to go to other countries and experience them. Why should you be a Seagoing Cowgirl? I think you should be a Seagoing Cowgirl because you can have many adventures, you can meet new animals, and you can also meet new people. Thats why I thing you should should be a Seagoing Cowgirl. You will never get tired of be a Seagoing Cowgirl.
