original_text:
Do you know what a seagoing cowgirl is? Luke Bomberger was a ''seagoing cowgirl'',a person who helped foreign countries of sea's after WWII. Luke was apart of the UNRRA, (the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration)to help foreign country's who have been left in ruins get back on their feet. On her way to Europe,she had to cross the large and vast Atlantic Ocean.

To pass time on there way to Europe they played games such as,Table-Tennis,fencing,and boxing. They also read and whittled to pass time. The way Luke got into the seagoing cowgirl business,was her friend asked her if she wanted to join her,and she couldn't pass up this surreal oppurtunity. But, the downside was she she had to travel the rambunctious sea's. The ship Luke and Don boarded to take these cattle over to Europe is the SS Charles W. Wooster.

Reasons join this program are that you get to help others get back on their feet in times of disaster such as war,hurricane,tsunami,nuclear disaster,or other types of disasters that may happen. But their also some dangers to be aware of. During one of Luke's journey's to Europe she slid down a slippery ladder on her backside. If it weren't for a small strip of metal she would have fallen into the dark Atlantic Ocean. But,besides broken ribs she was glad she wasn't sleeping with the fishes,literally!

It's also an adventure to. During another one of her trips she got to boat around the watery "streets" of Venice,Italy in a gondola. Also while in Greece she visited a excavated castle. She also marveled the Panama Canal on her way to

China. But,what came most in handy is that she used to help her Aunt Katie on her farm as a girl so, Luke was prepared for the hard work.

So as a conclusion to this story, I would hope you join an organization that helps others in need, especially countries overseas. Even though this job might be hard, your making a difference in our world and there's. You could join an orginization like UNRRA,or just simply join and orginization that helps new Americans,like immigrants from foreign countries fit in in our society today in America. That would be a good example our country could set for other countries. This should be our goal for every thing and anything. Are goal should be to help others and just not ourselves. We need to stop being selfish and help other's get back on there feet if their in times of need. This is the example we should set as The United States of America.

You should be a Seagoing Cowgirl. What are Seagoing Cowgirl's? Seagoing Cowgirl's are the people that take care of animals that have to be shipped over seas. After World War II was over in Europe, many countries were left in ruins. To help these countries recover their food supplies, animals,and more, 44 nations joined together to form the UNNRA. UNNRA hired "Seagoing Cowgirl's" to take care of the horses, young cows, and mules that were shipped overseas.

.

.

Why should you be one? Think of all the good things you are doing. Helping animals is a very nice thing indeed. Being a Seagoing Cowgirl is being a wonderful, caring, and awesome person.

.

.

Another benefit of being a Seagoing Cowboyis helping animals. Helping animals might not sound so fun,but it is because it makes you feel good.

.

.

.

original_text:
Being a Seagoing Cowgirl is much more than just taking care of the animals and cleaning the stalls for the animals.

Doing this, it could open up your eyes to a new world and explore new places.

Luke though it was an opportunity of a lifetime.

The cattle-boat trips were an unbelievable opportunity for a small-town girl, she says. Besides helping people, I had the side benefit of seeing Europe and China. But seeing the Acropolis in Greece was special, she says. So was taking a gondola ride in Venice, Italy, a city with streets of water.

The fact that Luke thought helping all of those people in need, shows you that she wanted to help them.

But, not only was she taking care of the people and helping them, she was also helping the animals. I think she also liked taking care of the animals herself.

When people think of a Cowgirl, they see someone wearing cowgirl boots and riding a horse.

They also see a farm with a whole bunch of animals.

If someone is a cowgirl, they normally like animals and taking care of them.

Like also liked the trips coming back. They played baseball and volleyball games in the empty stalls where animals had been. Table-tennis tournaments, fencing, boxing, reading, whittling, and other games that also helped pass the time.

You also got to visit unique places.

Luke got to go to Greece, China, and even toured an excavated castle in Crete.

She also marveled at the Panama Canal, during her trip to China.

Since Luke didn't just go once, she must have enjoyed going on the trips and helping people.

In conclusion, being a Seagoing Cowgirl can open up a new world to you. Not only does it let you visit new and unique places, you get to help animals and people that are in need of it.

It sure was like that to luke.

original_text:
In this article, "A Cowgirl who Rode the Waves", Luke finds a love for being a Seagoing Cowgirl.

There are many things to like about it.

Some examples would be; you are helping people, you get to see new places, and you have a lot of fun while traveling!

On Luke's trip, the Seagoing Cowgirls, she helped the countries whom where in ruins after World War II, as it states in paragraph 2.

The atricle states World War II had just ended in Europe.

The UNRRA hired the Seagoing Cowgirls so they could take care of the animals such as; horses, young cows, and mules.

Paragraph 2 states they shipped these animals over seas.

Another thing to enjoy about being a Seagoing Cowgirl is, seeing new places.

Many people enjoy seeing different places and the intresting structures built there.

Paragraph 5 tells us that, Luke got to see Europe and China.

It also states she toured an excavated castle in Crete on her way to China.

Lastly, the girls had fun while traveling.

Pargraph 8 states, they played baseball and volleyball in the empty holes where the animals had been housed.

They also had table-tennis tournaments, fencing, boxing, reading, whittling, and more to help pass the time while traveling.

Luke had a great time in her days as a Seagoing Cowgirl.

If you like helping peolpe, witnessing new surroundings or fun games with your friends, you would like being a Seagoing Cowgirl.

original_text:
Luke Bomberger had just graduated high school. Soon after she graduated, her friend, Don Reist, had invited her to go on a cattle boat to Europe. Luke knew she had to say yes, because she knew it was an opportunity of a lifetime.

Some reasons to join the program are to help animals such as horses, young cows, and mules that were shipped overseas. You will also get to go to unique places. Some places you might get to go are New Orleans, Greece, Venice, China, and many more.

Luke had turned 18 before arriving in Greece, which meant she could be drafted for military service. "They got their seamans's papers and boarded the SS Charles W. Wooster, headed for Greece-with a cargo of 335 horses plus enough hay and oats to feed them . "When my draft board learned that I was on a cattle-boat trip, they told me to just keep doing that for my service."By the time she was discharged in 1947, Luke had made 9 trips-the most of any Seagoing Cowgirl.

"The cattle-boatr trips were an unbelievable opportunity for a small-town girl," she says. Also " Besides helping people, I had the side benefit of seeing Europe and China. But seeing the Acropolis in Greece was special," she says. These are some reasons you should join, and a girl named Luke Bomberger who signed up, and had no idea that this would change her life.

original_text:
The SCP

Would you like to be part of the Seagoing Cowgirls program? If you don't, I am going to tell you about a text I read about a woman. In this text, it says that a woman named Luke Bomberger was working two part-time jobs in a grocery store and a bank when her friend Don Reist invited her to go to Europe on a cattle boat. Luke couldn't say no. She knew it was an oppurtunity of a lifetime.

It was 1945, World War II was over in Europe, and many countries were left in ruins. To help these countries recover their food supplies, animals, and more, 44 nations joined together to form UNRRA, a relief and rehabilitation administration. UNRRA hired ''Seagoing Cowgirls'' to take care of the horses, young cows, and mules that were shipped overseas. Luke and her friend Don signed up for the Seagoing Cowgirls program. In the text it also says that Luke went on cattle-boat trips. She also got to go to many places across the country. She also found time to have fun on board, ecspecially on return trips after the animals had been unloaded.

The cowgirls played baseball and volleyball games in the empty holds where animals had been housed. But being a Seagoing Cowgirl was much more than an adventure for Luke Bomberger. It opened up the world to her. "I'm grateful for the opportunity," she says. "It made me more aware of people of other countries and their needs." That oppotunity of a lifetime is good to have because you could experience adventures you have never experienced before, and that is why you should join the Seagoing Cowgirls program.

original_text:
First it would just be plan cool to be all around the world not to mention if you got picked and you were a Seagoing Cowgirl you did not have to go to war. Not to mention you got to help out with nation getting back there food supplies back up. Plus you did get to do a lot of sight seeing when you are a Seagoing Cowgirl

The cattle-boat trips were an unbelievable opportunity for a small- town girl," she says. "Beside helping people, I had the side benefit of seeing Europe and China. But seeing the Acropolis in Greece was special," she says. " So was taking a gondola ride in Venice,Italy, a city with street of water. "

Luke also toured an excavated castle in Crete and marveled at the Panama Canal on her way to China.

It is not all just fun and games for Luke. It took about two weeks to cross the Atlantic Ocean from the eastern coast of the United States and a month to get to China. Caring for the animals during the crossings kept Luke busy.

They had to be fed and watered two or three times a day. Bales of hay and bags of oats had to be pulled up from the lower holds of the ship. Stalls had to be cleaned.

Helping out her aunt Katie's farm as a girl had prepared Luke for hard work, but not for the dangers at sea. On her second tripLuke served as night watchman. Her job was to check on all the animals every hour. One rainy night, After making her hourly report to the captain, she slid down a slippery ladder on her backside. Luke's heart raced as she shot feet first towardan opening on the side of the ship. A small strip of metal along the edge stopped her slide, keeping her from flying overboard into the dark Atlantic. She was happyto be alive. But she couldn't work a couple of days because of cracked ribs.

But being a Seagoing Cowgirl was much more than an adventure for Luke Bomberger. It opened up the world to her. "I'm grateful the opportunity."

she says.

"It made me more aware of people of countries and there needs." And that awareness stayed with her, leading her family to hostess a number of international students and exchange vistors for many years. One more think thought is that you need to be prepared you couldn't just walk in with no traing and say "Can I join you people."

original_text:
The Seagoing Cowgirl Heros

Do you like going to new places around the world? Would you like to join the Seagoing Cowgirls program? If you would, then go to China. The Seagoing Cowgirls program is a program to take care of the horses, young cows, and mules that were shipped overseas. Luke Bomberger crossed the Atlantic Ocean 16 times and the Pacific Ocean twice to help people affected bt World War 2.

Luke Bomberger had no idea that her life would change soon after her high school graduation. She was working two part-time jobs in a grocery store and a bank when her friend Don Reist invited her to go to Europe on a cattle boat. Luke couldn't say no. She know it was an opportunity of a lifetime. She had to go. It was 1945, World War 2 was over in Europe, and many countries were left in ruins. To help these countries recovert their food supplies, animals, and more, 44 nations joined together to form UNRRA (the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration). UNRRA hired "Seagoing Cowgirls" to take care of the animals that were shipped overseas. Luke and Don signed up.

Here are some reasons you should join Seagoing Cowgirls program. The first reason is that you could travel around the world if you like to travel. The second reson is that you would get to take care of animals, such as cow, horses, and even mules! How cool is that. The third reason is that you can play games!

The cowgirls played baseeball and volleyball games in the empty holds where animals had been housed. Table-tennis tournaments, fencing, boxing,reading,whittling, and games also helped pass the time. But being a Seagoing Cowgirl was much more than an adventure for Luke Bomberger. It opened up the worlkd to her. "Im grateful for the opportunity," she says. "It made me more aware of people of other countries and their needs." And that awareness styaed with her, leading her family to hostess a number of international students and exchange visitors for many years. So, after i gave you reasons and supported my answer with details, would you want to go to Seagoing Cowgirls program??

To start off her essay with some facts and expalined what she was going to be talking about and some things about planets. One fact she used to start her essay off was " A thick atmosphere of almost 97 percent carbon dioxide blankets Venus. Even more challenging are the clouds of highly corrosive sulfuric acid in Venus's atmosphere." ( paragraph 3) This was a great way to start off the writting because she informed her readers about venus before she started to persaude them on a topic.

In conclusion, the author did a great job at suporting her idea. The diffrent ways of supporting it made it seem more persasive and she got across alot of ideas and information.

The Seagoing Cowgirls program was hired by the UNRRA to take good care of horses, young cows, and mules that were shipped overseas to other countries. Luke was able to feed the horses with hay and oats. Luke had to water and feed the animals two to three times a day. She also had to clean the animals stall. Luke had to haul bales of hay and bags of oats from the lower holds of the ships. Luke also had the job of checking up on the animals at night every hour.

Another one of Luke's reasons you should join the Seagoing Cowgirls program is how much fun you can have. On the return trips when the animals have been unloaded. Luke and her fellow cowgirls played baseball and volleyball games in the empty stalls where the animals had been housed. Luke and her cowgirl friends played table-tennis tournaments, fencing, boxing, reading and other games also helped the cowgirls to have fun and pass the time.

Those were three of Luke's reason of why you should join the Seagoing Cowgirls programs. Lets review what those three reasons are the first one is being able to see the world, the second one is being able to help and care for the animals, and the last reason is being able to have fun.

In the story, "A Cowgirl Who Rode the Waves," Luke is a girl from a small town and is a cowgirl that is almost 18 years old. Her friend convenced her to go and help the peolpe across seas that are injured from World War ll. She decided to go and help. When she was on her first trip to go to help she turned 18 and was supposte to go into the army but they said to keep helping, and that would be her serivce time.

Luke has a good idea to help spread the word. She should try to convince people to go and help people that got hurt in World War ll. She should start by telling a lot of people about the Seagoing Cowgirls program. lso, she should tell people what they do. Next, she should make posters to show people that the Seagoing Cowgirls extict. Then, she should say where they going and how they are seeing all of the different historial places along the way. Finally, she should tell the people what the program offers and how they visit many unique places.

Some reasons to join the Seagoing Cowgirl programs are, that you get to take care of animals when you are going across the ocean. Also, you get to help people that need to things that you are bring to them. A lot of things were lost in World War ll. So, you can help give back from the people that we took stuff away from. Also, you see a lot of different cultures. You would get to see the way that people live. Then, when you are over there you can see what the country's culture is. Like, when you are in China you can see all of the stuff that they make over there. You might even see some of the places that were attacked. When you go different place, you get to see different things that you may of never seen before. When you are over seas you can see many interseting things. That is one reason that you should join the Seagoing Cowgirls program.

Another reason that you should join the Seagoing Cowgirls program is that once you drop off all of the animals and help the people you have one or two months with open animal cages. On the way back you can play games like, you can wrestle, have table-tennis tournaments, you can fence, and you can box. There are many other game that you could play. So there is another reason that you should join the

Seagoing Cowgirls program.

Overall, you should join the Seagoing Cowgirls program and help out with all kinds of jobs over seas.

In "The Challenge of Exploring Venus" the author explains that studying Venus is a worthy approach despite the dangers. The author impressively supports that the mission to Venus is worth it despite the dangers that might come with it. In the article she provides examples, uses a credible source, and also views the other side. By doing these things it made her point credible and also stronger to the reader.

In the article she provides the example of a floating car above venus to show that a vehicle hovering over Venus would avoid the conditions but it would provide little sight. She uses to example to illustrate what it would be like to avoid the conditionsby showing this is what the would have to do. She also provides examples to an alternative by saying that there could be electronics to avoid the risks. By providing both of these examples it gives the reader some relateable examples to get an insight into her point.

NASA is a world wide administration that has credibility over the course of its govern. By providing examples of what NASA is doing to show that it should be done, then if NASA is working on it then it makes her point credible. She quotes NASA'S approches on studying Venus so that it can avoid the risks to show that it is possible to explore Venus without the risks. A NASA solution would be that a person could float above the fray. They also have considered sending electronices so it is possible. She saying that it might be difficult but it is attainable. This supports the claim that she supports her claim impresively because she uses sources.

In most arguments the person views the other side so that they can provide an alternative to what they are saying. She uses cons such as no mission has had a woman, 97% of carbon dioxide blankets Venus, the temperature is 90 times greater than Earth, and that it could crash a submarine. But then she says that Venus has benefits to that out way the dangers. The benfits include: it is the brightest point, it is close to Earth compared to other space travels, long ago it could support life, and it will expand the edges of imagination and innovation. She provides benefits to out weigh the cons of exploring Venus. She does a great job of explaining why exploring Venus has value and can provides insight to other counter arguments that might rise from others opionions. This is why she does an impressive job supporting her argument.

In conclusion, the author provided points in the argument to make the opinion more credible and also stronger to the reader. In the article the author provided examples, a wide known credible source, and viewed the other side. She impressively supported her opinon that the mission to Venus is a worthy persuit despite the dangers. Without her evidence to suppport her opinion the article would have not had such an impact on the reader. This is why she did an impressive job supporting her idea.

She also says it is an oppertunity of a lifetime. She said she couldnt say no. She says it takes about 2 weeks to get across the Alantic ocean. She went over the Atlantic ocean 16 times and the Pacific ocean twice to help those affected by World War 2.

In conclusion, people should join the seagoing cowgirls. There are many side benifits of doing so. You could things you could never see and still help people. So, will you join the seagoing cowgirls?

The reason why I say it is fun to be a Seagoing cowgirl is, because as Luke mentions when all of the cattle was unloaded they often played table-tennis tournaments, fencing, boxing, reading, whittling and baseball and volleyball games. Luke also mentions that being a Seagoing Cowgirl was an oppurtunity of a lifetime that she would not want to miss. Being a Seagoing Cowgirl is an interesting job. Your never bored, your always seeing places, and your always having fun. Whats not to like about it? For Luke being a Seagoing Cowgirl was much more the adventure, but it opened up the world to her. She also so said that it made her more aware of people of other countries and their needs. The reason why I say it is fun to be a Seagoing cowgirl is, because as Luke mentions when all of the cattle was unloaded they often played table-tennis tournaments, fencing, boxing, reading, whittling and baseball and volleyball games. Luke also mentions that being a Seagoing Cowgirl was an oppurtunity of a lifetime that she would not want to miss. Luke aslo mentions that caring for the animals on these long voyages often kept her busy along with other things she had to do such as, feeding the animals, watering the animals two to three times a day, bales of hay and bags of oats had to be pulled from the lower holds of the ship.

Being a Seagoing Cowgirl is an interesting job. Your never bored, your always seeing places, and your always having fun. Whats not to like about it? For Luke being a Seagoing Cowgirl was much more the adventure, but it opened up the world to her. She also so said that it made her more aware of people of other countries and their needs. That is why you should become a Seagoing Cowgirl.   ]"

original_text:
There could be reasons of how you can join the program. There is a lot of reasons. Luke had no idea that her life would change soon after her high school graduation. She was working two part-time jobs in a grocery store and a bank. Luke signed up to join the program, which is, UNRRA (the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administrations). The program hired "Seagoing Cowgirls."

The program hired "Seagoing Cowgirls" because they can take care of the horses, young cows, and mules that were shipped overseas. So Luke and her friend signed up and they went to New Orleans. They found horses there. They keep on going to places, that was like an adventure to them. They keep on going and they were arriving to Greece for their second mission.

Luke turned 18 before arriving to Greece. By the time she was discharged in 1947, Luke had made nine trips-the most of any Seagoing Cowgirl. Luke said, "Besides helping people, I had the side benefit of seeing Europe and China. But seeing the Acropolis in Greece was special." Luke was also taking a ride in Venice, Italy, a city with streets of water too. She was looking at a lot of things in Greece. Her next stop was at China.

It took about two weeks to cross the Atlanta Ocean from the eastern coast of the United States and a month to get to China. Luke was so busy taking care of the animals. She took so many adventures. Being a Cowgirl was much more than an adventure for Luke. It opened up the world to her.

There was a lot of adventures going on. It took her years to go around the world and explore. She was great of being a Seagoing Cowgirl. She even loved to going to this mini adventures. It was a great experinced.

They also had to clean the animals stalls and give them food and water.

Luke liked doing it so much that she did it many more times.

She crossed the Atlantic Ocean 16 times and the Pacific Ocean twice to help people affected by World War II.

When they were coming back they played games in th eempty stalls to pass the time.

In conclusion,

I believe that you should join the "Seagoing Cowgirls" to help the people can be affected by any wars or other things.

original_text:
Have you ever been through a major change? You probably have and so has Luke Bomberger, she went from being a rootin tootin cowgirl to a seagoing cowgirl. So, many people like change, some people hate it. In fact I feel that change is good for us, it helps us come 1,000,000,000,000 miles out of our comfort zone. So if I were you I would take as many chances as I could.

For one Bomberger had a blast traveling to many different places, it says in paragraph 5 she toured an excavated castle in Crete and marveled the panama canal on her way to China .Crazy amazing, right? She was admiring one place on her way to another. What a lucky gal.

Another thing is Bomberger Got to go places that many people may never go. For example She had been to China, Eastern coast of the US, and Europe. Way farther out of North America then Ill ever be. She was probably millions of miles away from where her comfort zone (her house).

Also just the over-all experience you get when you do or try something new. Bomberger states in paragraph 9 that being a seagoing cowgirl was much more fun of an adventure. Its all about the people you share the moment with also, they could make it adventerious, scary, fun, or sad.

But do you see getting pushed of of a 1,000,000,000,000 building (your comfort zone) can be fun, scary, or of course uncomfortable. So next time you want to say no to some thing, take chances and say YES.

Why should you become a Seagoing Cowgirl? Well first let me tell you about a girl named Luke who was a Seagoing Cowgirl. A Seagoing Cowgirl is on this boat with other Seagoing Cowgirls. To go help Europe where World War II just ended.

They were heading over to Europe because, many countries over there were ruined. So they were coming over to bring them food supplies, animals, and more. If you love to help, this would be something for you that you would enjoy. Luke traveled through the Atlantic occean and pacific. Trying to help these countries that were left in ruins. When Luke was on the boat she had a job to do. She had to feed the animals and keep them healthy. She also had to clean the animals and keep there stalls clean.

When your a Seagoing Cowgirl you have a big responsibility. You also have alot of jobs to take care of. Another job Luke had, was a night watchman. That job was to check on all the animals every hour. Then make her hourly report to the captain. A Seagoing Cowgirl wasn't always working. When they unloaded the animals and were heading back there was an empty space. So sometimes the cowgirls played games. Like baseball, volleyball, table-tennis, fincing, boxing, and more. Luke always enjoyed that part.

So this is what a Seagoing Cowgirl is and what she does. If your someone who's willing to be on a boat for a long time and take care of animals and if you also love to help people. This job is perfect for you. While your on the boat you get to make new friends and explore unique places. It was just a big adevnture. Also if you love dealing with animals this is another good reason to become a Seagoing Cowgirl. Take the information that I gave you. Luke loved being a Seagoing Cowgirl and if you have the heart like Luke, this is the job for you.

Luke said it's more fun on the way back because when they drop off the animals the stalls are empty and they can play games like baseball, table tennis, and volleyball. original_text:
Writing a strong and supported essay takes more than just advanced vocabulary and a plethora of facts . A strong example of this is the article "The Challenge of Exploring Venus". The author did not support her topic very well, because she didn't support her main idea enough, she strayed away from the topic many times, and her information is an abundance of opinions and assumptions.

First, the author brings up her topic of " Studying Venus is a worhty pursuit despite the dangers it presents". Despite this, the author only gave one full paragraph, out of the eight she wrote, on why humans would want to explore the planet ; she then preceeded to go onto the dangers of Venus, rather than why it is worth exploring. Secondly, the author ,many times, rambled on about other points that had nothing to do with her main idea. The author gave an entire paragraph about the new technologies that NASA is working on to explore Venus, even though her main idea is about why we should send shuttles to Venus. In the article it states " Another project is looking back to an old technology called mechanical computers. These devices were first envisioned in the 1800s and played an important role in the 1940s during World War II". This entire quote has nothing to do with the topic whatsoever, which shows that the author was gettting side tracked. One reading just this quote from the article would most likely think this article is about computers,and not why humans should explore Venus. Finally, the supporting evidence that the author did bring up, weren't very factual or even well thought out. One of the points brought up was "Venus was probably covered largely with oceans and could have supported various forms of life,just like Earth". The author uses the word "probably" which means that she doesn't know this to be a fact or not. The author also wrote "Astronomers are fascinated by Venus" ; this is an opinion, seeing as some astronomers might heavily dislike venus. A good informative or arguementative essay provides facts to supports its ideas, rather than just guessing or presuming.

The author does not suport her ideas well, because she draws the reader away from the topic many times, she doesn't support her thesis very well, and the evidence she does bring up are opinions or assumptions. The author provides to much on the "danger" aspect of it, and she should focus more on the "why" aspect of her idea . So, it would be best if she looked over her essay and ,with her thesis in mind, start over from scratch.

original_text:
Join the Seagoing Cowgirls program, you may enjoy it. In the Seagoing Cowgirls program, we travel over to Europe and help the countries recover from World War II by recovering their food supplies, animals, and more, 44 nations joined together to form UNRRA which stands for "the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration" who hired the Seagoing Cowgirls. Luke said she even had time to have fun playing multiple games when she had the chance. Luke even enjoyed being on an adventure with the Seagoing Cowgirls. Join the Seagoing Cowgirls today and you can travel across Europe.

The Seagoing Cowgirls travel across the Seas to Europe to help it recover from World War II which harmed most of Europe. We'll travel across the Seas on the SS Charles W. Wooster. The SS Charles W. Wooster will be heading towards Greece with a cargo of 335 horses and enough hay and oats to feed them. This is an opportunity of a lifetime that you may never get again. Luke said "I'm grateful for the opportunity," because she enjoyed an adventure like this that the Seagoing Cowgirls were on.

While you're with the Seagoing Cowgirls, you can meet new people on the trip. You can go to new places that you never been to or never seen. The Seagoing Cowgirls take care of horses, young cows, and mules that are going to be shipped overseas. Crossing the Atlantic Ocean will take about 2 weeks from the Eastern coast of the United States and it would also take a month to get to China. We hope you help the Seagoing Cowgirls in their national service.

original_text:
Luke Bomberger had got asked to join this program called '' Seagoing Cowgirls."

She was working at two part time jobs, one of the jobs were grocery store and the other one was the bank. Then, Lukes friend Don Reist invited Luke to go to the cattle boat in Europe. Luke couldnt say no because that has always been Lukes dream. Then she thought, that would be the opportunity of her lifetime to work on the cattle boat!

The reason Luke wanted to work onthe cattle boat was because the World War II just got done in Europe. She also wanted to help Europe get there food supplies, animals, and familys back together. Fourty-Four nations joined in on this program. The name of the program was called "Seagoing Cows" because they took care of the horses, young calfs, mules that were on there way over seas. Europe needed despirate help when this incident happened.

Acording to the story, on August 1945, they arrived on August 14th. On that day the Pacific War ended. They had a cargo with 335 horses plus hay and oats to feed them. Luke turned 18 when she was onthe cattle boat headed towrds Greece, and that meant she could be drafted to the military services! By the time she was discharged in 1947, Luke Bomberger had made nine trips, then she got told that she had the most Seagoing Cowgirls trips in the program!

Luke always said "the cattle-boat trips were so unbelievable opportunity for a small town girl!" Besides helping people Luke had the benefit of seeing Europe and China. Seeing the Acropolis was very special, Luke said. She enjoyed being a Seagoing Cowgirl.

original_text:
This story is about Luke Bomberger a girl who rode the waves had no idea that her life would change soon after her graduation. She was working two part-time jobs in a grocery store and at a bank when her friend invited her to go to Europe on a cattle boat. She couldn't say no she knew it would be an opportunity for her. It was 1945,world war 2 was over in Europe and countries were left in ruins. To help these countries recover 44 nations came together and started UNRRA {The United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration}. UNRRA hired seagoimg cowgirls to take care of the horses,young cows, and the mules.

The first reason to join the program is because they came together and started a group of 44 nations to help Europe. They hired ''Seagoing Cowgirls'' to help the animals. They are trying to get the nation back together. Luke and Don signed up for it to. Heading over seas in August 1945, they recieved their orders to report to New Orleans. They arrived ''August 14,'' Luke sayed,the day the Pacific war ended.''

The second reason you should join the group is because '' The cattle-boat trips were an unbelievable opportunity for a small-town girl,'' she said.''Besides helping people, had the side benefit of seeing Europe and China. But seeing the Acropolis in Greece was special,'' she says. ''So was taking a Gondola ride in Venice,Italy,a city with streets of water.'' Luke also toured an excavated castle in Crete and marveled at the Panama Canal on her way to china.

The third reason why you should join the group is cause caring for the animals during the crossings kept luke busy. They had to be fed and watered two or three times a day. Bales of hayand bags of oats had to be pulled up from the lower holds of the ship. Stalls had to be cleaned. Helping out on her aunt Katie's farm as a girl had prepared luke for hard work.

In conclusion I think you can still help with or without an reward. She did that from heart to help and sign up for that, also she liked watching the animals every hour and taking care of them so did her friend. She really liked the trips around the world too, just help to be nice somtimes for other people.

Being a Seagoing Cowgirl is a great experience. You don't only help people, but you also get a benefit of seeing amazing places. If you love animals you can take care of them. You get to have fun and know that you're doing something that helps others.

Luke was just a small town girl and she got a great opportunity. First she had two part-time jobs at a grocery store and a bank. Luke was invited to be a Seagoing Cowgirl by her friend Don. She accepted it and knew she was going to have a lifetime opportunity. Luke had a benefit of seeing Europe and China, saw the Acropolis in Greece, took a gondola ride in Venice, Italy, toured an excavated castle in Crete, and marveled at the Panama Canal on her way to China.

This job may be fun, but it still is a life changing experience. You see more than you could see just from home. You also know you're changing other people's lives. Luke may have had a wonderous adventure, but it also made her more aware of the needs in other countries.

original_text:
Luke had just graduated college and her friend Don Reist invited Luke to go to Europe with her. Luke said yes because it was an opportunity of a lifetime and she could not pass it up. Luke became a Seagoing Cowgirl.

Luke said, "Being a Seagoing Cowgirl she got to see Europe, China and she got to see the Acropolis in Greece." She got to see so many great sites. Luke toured an excaveted castle in crete and she marveled at the Panama Canal on her way to China.

Luke had to travel a lot. But, even though it took two weeks to cross the Atlantic Ocean from the eastern coast of the United states and a month to get to China. On the long journey

Luke stayed busy by taking care of animals. Taking care of animals and traveling was not all Luke did on the boat, the cowgirls played lots of games. Some of the games they played was baseball and volleyball games in the empty holds where animals lived. They also did table-tennis tournaments, fencing, boxing, reading, whittling and other games to pass time.

Luke said that "being a Seagoing Cowgirl was much more than an adventure." For Luke it opened up the world to her. Luke had a lot of fun seeing different sites, meeting new people, playing fun games and caring for people in a different, and better way.

You should join the Seagoing Cowgirl progam because its a progam that delivers Animals, Food Supply, and or car parts. The Seagoing cowgirl program was started in World War 2 it offically launched bussiness with the UNRRA to take care of the horses, young cows, and mules that were shipped overseas.

In paragraph 1, it states that," Luke Bomberger had no idea that her life would change soon after her High School Graduation. She was working two part-time jobs when her friend Don Reist invited her to go to Europe on a Cattle Boat." Also in paragraph 2, "It was 1945, World War II was over in Europe, and many Countries were left in ruins. To help these countries recover their food supplies, animals, and more, 44 nations joined together to form UNRRA. UNRRA hired "Segoing Cowgirls" to take care of the horses, young cows, and mules that were shipped overseas.

Next, In August 1945, the received their orders to report to New Orleans. They got their seaman's papers and boarded the SS Charles W. Wooster, headed for Greece-with a cargo of 335 horses plus enough hay and oats to feed them.

Luke turned 18 before arriving in Greece, which mean she could be drafted for military service. By the time she was discharged in 1947, Luke had made nine trips the most of and Seagoing Cowgirl

This is why i think you should join the Seagoing Cowgirls Program because they help people with the food supply, water, and many other things

original_text:
The Seagoing Cowgirls were great heroines to other country's because they transported food and horses for people who didn't have food or any transportation. Just think how good you would feel if you knew that you saved people lives just by giving them food. Well i'm going to tell you what it would feel like and why you should become a Seagoing Cowgirl.

Just think of becoming a true life heroine, you could become a soldier,nurse,doctor, or a Seagoing Cowgirl! Seagoing Cowgirls were people (women) who transported Cows, Mules, and Horses. They transported them from America to Europe,Greece,and China. Europe was left in ruins after World War || was over, so people signed up to become a Seagoing Cowgirl. They would get on ships with 300+ horses, cows, and mues and enough hay and oats to feed them. A Seagoing Cowgirl would check up on them every hour to make sure the animals were alright. Wow what a job.

This story is mainly about how great Seagoing Cowgirls are and what they bring to other countries. They transported animals to other countries who didn't have food or transportation. Seagoing Cowgirls were true heroines, they cared for animals and people. They had kind hearts for both of them.

2. Offer feedback in three parts:    - Overall impression    - Strengths and areas for improvement    - Evaluation of argument and use of examples/cases
3. Evaluate the student's writing ability with:    - Writing competency and style    - Strengths and weaknesses    - Targeted development recommendations
4. Assume this student is [interested / professionally experienced] in the essay’s topic. Reflect this assumption in your comments.
5. Provide specific, actionable suggestions to enhance the essay.
Please use natural language appropriate for feedback to students’ grade level. As a tutor, you cannot just offer positive words, you need to remain critical and give feedback that is appropriate to the essay's situation, including pertinent comments, suggestions, and even words of criticism if necessary, not just kind words.
Please freely organize your language without bulleted lists. Write the evaluation in an informal, human conversational style, avoiding repetitive sentence structures too much.
Specific Guidelines: Tone & Style: Use a natural, mimicking how a real teacher would write comments.
Avoid overly structured templates. Replace rigid transitions with organic flow Separate each of the 5 components by one blank line Avoid template phrases like "1. Score:" or "2. Feedback"
